qas.question: What office is responsible for the census form changes?

answers.text: the Office of Management and Budget (OMB)

qas.question: When did the OMB change racial guidelines for the census form?
When were the OMB racial directive made mandatory for every government form?
What did the OMB vote to allow on the 2000 census?

answers.text: participants to select more than one of the six available categories

qas.question: When did the OMB change federal regulations of racial categories to bar multiple responses?
In what year were participants no longer allowed to choose more than one of the six available categories?
What was not one of the categories participants could choose on the 2000 United States Census?
When did the OMB directive stop being mandatory on government forms?
What office is barred from making changes to the census form?

context: Multiracial people who wanted to acknowledge their full heritage won a victory of sorts in <a1_0><b4_0>1997<b4_0/><a1_0/>, when <a0_0>the <b8_0>Office of Management and Budget<b8_0/> (OMB)<a0_0/> changed the federal regulation of racial categories to permit multiple responses. This resulted in a change to the <b5_0>2000<b5_0/> United States Census, which allowed <a3_0>participants to select more than one of the six available categories<a3_0/>, which were, in brief: "<b6_0>White<b6_0/>," "Black or African American," "Asian," "American Indian or Alaskan Native," "Native Hawaiian or other Pacific Islander," and "Other." Further details are given in the article: Race (U.S. census). The OMB made its directive mandatory for all government forms by <a2_0><b7_0>2003<b7_0/><a2_0/>.
